Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Research in Undergraduate STEM Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is engaging 10 undergraduate students per year in summer research experiences at North Dakota State University in the area of STEM education. The students are conducting research under the guidance of a faculty mentor while learning from each other. The students are learning qualitative and quantitative research methods, scientific communication skills, and becoming familiar with career paths in STEM Education Research. These students are being uniquely prepared for PhD-level training in STEM education research at this institution and others with programs in this rapidly growing area. The institution is building on its strengths in discipline-based education research in biochemistry education, biology education, chemistry education, physics education and math education. The research projects that students are engaging in are integrating across STEM disciplines, and they include: studying how undergraduate students learn quantitative reasoning skills, develop systems thinking, and learn visualization skills, as well as how to close achievement gaps between various groups in science and mathematics. This project is advancing knowledge and understanding of effective teaching and learning in STEM while providing an authentic research experience to undergraduates. Students from groups underrepresented in STEM are being targeted for recruitment in this program, including undergraduates at Sitting Bull College, a Tribal College.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The awarding of the National Science Foundation (NSF) Grant #1156974 under the Division of Undergraduate Education marked the beginning of a unique program in the growing field of Discipline-based Education Research. While the NSF has a long tradition of funding Undergraduate Research through its Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Programs, the funding of such a program in Interdisciplinary Research in Undergraduate STEM Education has only occurred a handful of times. The Growing Up STEM REU Experience at North Dakota State University has seen the recruitment and mentoring of 30 undergraduate researchers from across the United States in an attempt to place or keep them on the path for graduate education opportunities.

 

The key outcomes of the Growing Up STEM REU are:

1. Provide participants with experience in DBER to facilitate informed decisions regarding career pathways and opportunities in DBER.

2. Enable participants to develop hands-on and critical thinking skills to facilitate their engagement and future success in research.

3. Foster an understanding and appreciation of the collaborative and collegial nature of research through participation in a collaborative research environment.

4. Encourage participants to evaluate the implications of DBER research on teaching and learning in the undergraduate classroom.

5. Increase the participants’ science communication skills through dissemination of research via posters and oral presentations at local, regional, and national conferences.

 

For the lifetime of the Growing Up STEM REU at NDSU we had 30 REU students working on 30 separate projects and were mentored by six STEM Ed faculty across disciplines of Biology, Chemistry and Biochemistry, and Physics. Jeff Boyer (College of Science and Mathematics), Lisa Montplaisir (Biology), Erika Offerdahl (Chemistry and Biochemistry), Mila Kryjevskaia (Physics), James Nyachwaya (Chemistry and Biochemistry), Jennifer Momsen (Biology), and Warren Christensen (Physics) served as faculty mentors during the three summers.

Throughout the program, REU students participated in weekly professional development, individual meetings with their mentor, lab meetings, and social activities. The weekly professional development seminars brought together all the STEM Ed REU students at least once per week. These seminars developed skills for research and future success in graduate school. Topics for these seminars included maintaining a lab book, conducting literature searches and familiarization with NDSU resources, oral presentations, poster creation and presentation, ethics in scientific research, scientific writing and publishing, collaboration in research, academic careers and beyond, and the graduate school experience from the perspective of active graduate students. More details on these seminars can be found in the key outcomes section. In addition, REU students each gave an informal chalk talk to the REU community to practice articulating their research and provided students an opportunity to provide critical feedback.

REU students met individually with faculty mentors to discuss research, including methods and analysis, and to synthesize readings from the primary literature. The frequency of the meetings varied with mentors and REU students. Most mentors reported meeting with students individually between 1 and 9 hours per week.

Group (lab) meetings took place once or twice per week depending on the group. These provided opportunities to analyze and synthesize literature and present data to the lab group. For instance, Drs. Momsen and Montplaisir held a mini-Journal Club that featured weekly reading of papers and student-led discussions. Dr. Montplaisir held sessions for those REU students who are on a pre-service teaching trajectory to discuss reformed-based teaching.

REU students took part in a number of social events led by faculty, including a rib cooking festival, a local baseball game, a welcoming picnic, downtown street fair, and an end of program farewell BBQ. The students found our Facebook group page incredibly useful for planning and implementing social activities. An emergent feature of our program was students used an across-platform app called GroupMe for easily communicating with each other and planning events. Faculty mentors seeded numerous ideas for events in the Fargo-Moorhead area, students did so as well, apart from the faculty mentors. They coordinated trips to community events, such as music concerts, fairs in downtown, movie nights, and other vacations with students from within the cohort.

The REU Program at NDSU, from all available data sources including feedback from faculty mentors, our external evaluation report that included interviews with all REU participants, and informal feedback form REUs, was incredibly successful. There are no significant changes planned for the general structure or the running of our program that are based on negative feedback beyond 2015.
